\UseRawInputEncoding

Tighter Regret Analysis and Optimization of Online Federated Learning

Dohyeok Kwon, , Jonghwan Park,  and Songnam Hong D. Kwon and S. Hong are with the Department of Electronic Engineering, Hanyang University, Seoul, 04763, Korea.
E-mail: {kwon1585,snhong}@hanyang.ac.kr J. Park is with the Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Southern California, CA, 90089, USA.
E-mail: jonghwan@usc.edu
Abstract

In federated learning (FL), it is commonly assumed that all data are placed at clients in the beginning of machine learning (ML) optimization (i.e., offline learning). However, in many real-world applications, it is expected to proceed in an online fashion. To this end, online FL (OFL) has been introduced, which aims at learning a sequence of global models from decentralized streaming data such that the so-called cumulative regret is minimized. Combining online gradient descent and model averaging, in this framework, FedOGD is constructed as the counterpart of FedSGD in FL. While it can enjoy an optimal sublinear regret, FedOGD suffers from heavy communication costs. In this paper, we present a communication-efficient method (named OFedIQ) by means of intermittent transmission (enabled by client subsampling and periodic transmission) and quantization. For the first time, we derive the regret bound that captures the impact of data-heterogeneity and the communication-efficient techniques. Through this, we efficiently optimize the parameters of OFedIQ such as sampling rate, transmission period, and quantization levels. Also, it is proved that the optimized OFedIQ can asymptotically achieve the performance of FedOGD while reducing the communication costs by 99%percent9999\%. Via experiments with real datasets, we demonstrate the effectiveness of the optimized OFedIQ.

Index Terms:
Online learning, federated learning, distributed optimization, streaming learning, regret analysis.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is an emerging framework for distributed and privacy-preserving machine learning (ML), in which a central server coordinates ML optimization with a massive number of clients without directly sharing training data stored in the decentralized clients (i.e., local data) [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]. In FL, the clients train local models separately from local data and the central server constructs a global model only using the aggregated local models [6]. Specifically, a global model is learned by performing the two steps iteratively: i) local model optimizations (usually via stochastic gradient descent (SGD)) at each client; ii) global model optimization (e.g., model averaging) at the central server. There are myriads of applications such as ML from wearable devices [7], location-based services [8], and human activity recognition [9].

Recently, numerous FL methods have been proposed. FedSGD was introduced in [6], where a global model is optimized via local stochastic gradient descent (SGD) at clients and model averaging at a central server. Also, in [10], the convergence analysis of FedSGD was provided for both cases of identical and heterogeneous data. Incorporating client subsampling (or partial participation) and periodic averaging into FedSGD, the de facto optimization method (named FedAvg) was presented in [6], which has lower communication costs than FedSGD. In [11], a communication-efficient FL method (named FedPAQ) was proposed by integrating a stochastic quantization into FedAvg. To sophisticate a quantization method, vector quantizations suitable for FL were proposed in [12, 13, 14]. Also, an enhanced gradient-quantization technique, called Lazily Aggregated Quantized (LAQ) gradient, was presented in [15]. Interestingly, it was shown in [16, 17] that FedAvg suffers from the so-called ‘client-drift’ when the degree of data heterogeneity is high (i.e., non-IID data), resulting in unstable and slower convergence. This problem becomes more serious as the fraction of participating clients becomes smaller. Many works have put much effort into addressing the above problem. SCAFFOLD [17] and Variance Reduced Local-SGD (VRL-SGD) [18] employed extra control variates to accelerate the convergence by reducing the variance of stochastic gradients. FedProx [19] added a proximal term to each local optimizations in order to suppress the discrepancy among the local models. FedNova [20] normalized the magnitude of local updates across the clients in the network so that the model averaging less distracts the global loss.

1.1 Related Works

In most of the existing FL works, it is commonly assumed that features (or data) do not possess an associated inherent ordering (i.e., non-streaming data) and accordingly, all data samples are placed at clients in the beginning of ML optimization (i.e., offline learning). Existing FL methods, thus, have paid little attention to ML optimization from continuous streaming (or time-series) data. In many real-world applications, however, ML tasks are expected to be performed in an online fashion, wherein data samples are generated as a function of time and clients have to predict a label (or make a decision) upon receiving an incoming data. To handle such tasks, online FL (OFL) has been introduced in [21] by combining online learning (OL) (or streaming learning) [22] and FL. The goal of OFL is to seek a sequence of global models (or functions) in real time from continuous streaming data arriving at decentralized clients [21, 23]. At each time step, an up-to-date function is used to predict the label of newly incoming (previously unseen) data. The major difference between OFL methods and the aforementioned FL methods(e.g., FedAvg [6], FedPAQ[11], SCAFFOLD [17], FedProx [19], and FedNova [20]) is in the objective of local updates. While FL methods aim at seeking a sole global model that minimizes a global loss function, OFL methods aim at seeking a sequence of global models that minimizes the so-called cumulative regret (see Section 2) for details). Because of such difference, the existing FL methods may not ensure an optimal sublinear regret (i.e., an asymptotic optimality) for OFL. This opens up the necessity of new researches for OFL.

Very recently in [21], an OFL method based on random feature-based multiple kernels (named eM-KOFL) was presented and its asymptotic optimality was proved via martingale argument. This work was mainly focused on dealing with multiple kernels in a communication-efficient way. Especially when a single-kernel is considered, vanilla method (named FedOGD) was constructed and analyzed, which can be immediately applied to deep neural network (DNN)-based methods. Note that FedOGD can be regarded as the counterpart of FedSGD [6] in FL. While it can enjoy an optimal sublinear regret, FedOGD suffers from heavy communication costs. A communication-efficient OFL method (named PSO-Fed) was proposed in [23], where clients and a central server exchange a fraction of their model parameters: however, no regret analysis was conducted. These two methods employed online gradient descent (OGD) (which is commonly used for OL) as the underlying online optimization method to the clients. Leveraging online mirror descent (OMD) and periodic averaging, FedOMD was presented in [24]. Note that when a widely-used Euclidean distance is adopted as Bregman divergence, OMD is reduced to OGD [25]. It was proved that FedOMD can enjoy an optimal subliner regret. To the best of our knowledge, there is no additional OFL method with an analytical performance guarantee.

We emphasize that compared with FL, OFL researches are at an infancy level. In particular, the existing regret analyses have not considered the impact of the fundamental communication-efficient techniques (e.g., client subsampling, periodic transmission, and quantization), and data-heterogeneity over time and across clients. This is the motivation of our work since such analysis would be the stepping stone for the research of OFL.

1.2 Contributions

In this paper, OFL is investigated in terms of constructing a communication-efficient method and tighter regret analysis. We improve the communication-efficiency of the baseline method (FedOGD) via two fundamental techniques such as intermittent transmission of model updates and quantization of updated gradients (see Fig. 1). The former directly reduces the number of transmissions (or active communication channels) and the latter diminishes the number of transmitted bits per each active channel. The proposed method is referred to as Online Federated learning method with Intermittent transmission and Quantization (OFedIQ). Herein, intermittent transmission is enabled by client subsampling (a.k.a. partial client participation) and periodic transmission (a.k.a. periodic averaging), which stand for the infrequent transmissions across clients and over time steps, respectively. Our major contributions are summarized as follows.

  • •

    We derive tighter theory for OFL through a novel regret analysis. Our analysis is more rigorous than the existing ones such as the regret analysis of centralized OL [22, 26, 27] and the regret analyses of distributed and federated OL [28, 21, 29, 24]. This is because our regret bound can reflect for the first time the effects of data-heterogeneity and the communication-efficient techniques (e.g., client subsampling, periodic transmission, quantization) on learning accuracy.

  • •

    Through our analysis, we prove that OFedIQ over T𝑇T time steps can enjoy an optimal sublinear regret 𝒪​(T)𝒪𝑇{\cal O}(\sqrt{T}) for any dataset (up to a constant), where the constant is bigger as data-heterogeneity grows. Namely, OFedIQ has the same asymptotic performance as FedOGD (i.e., the performance-limit) while significantly reducing the communication costs (e.g., about 99%percent9999\% reduction).

  • •

    For practical non-asymptotic cases, it is required to optimize the key parameters of OFedIQ such as sampling rate, transmission period, and quantization levels. Leveraging our regret bound, we efficiently tackle such optimization problem, yielding almost closed-form solutions (see Algorithm 3). Given target communication costs, the proposed Algorithm 3 provides the optimal parameters of OFedIQ with respect to maximizing the asymptotic learning accuracy.

  • •

    Via experiments with real datasets, we demonstrate the superiority of the optimized OFedIQ on online classification and regression tasks. It can almost achieve the performance of FedOGD (i.e., the performance limit of communication-efficient OFL methods) while reducing the communication costs by 99%percent9999\%. Also, our method can outperform the benchmark methods such as OFedAvg and FedOMD for all datasets. These results suggest the practicality of the optimized OFedIQ.

1.3 Outline and Notations

The remaining part of this paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we formally define the objective and learning process of OFL. In Section 3.2, we introduce the vanilla method (named FedOGD) and enhance its communication-efficiency by means of intermittent transmission and quantization. The resulting method is named OFedIQ. A tighter regret analysis is conducted in Section 4 and on the basis of this analysis, we efficiently optimize the key parameters of OFedIQ. In Section 5, we verify the effectiveness of our algorithm via experiments with real datasets. Some concluding remarks are provided in Section 6.

2 Online Federated Learning (OFL)

We formally define an online federated Learning (OFL) [21, 24, 23]. Recall that in (conventional) FL, ML optimization is tackled under the assumption that each client has access to local data samples offline and such samples are generated statistically. Whereas, OFL is basically formed by combining online learning (OL) and FL. Compared to FL, thus, OFL has the following two major differences:

  • •

    Sequential data acquisition: At every time step, each client has access to newly incoming (previously unseen) data. As in OL [22], there is no statistical assumption on data samples. The detailed description of data acquisition in OFL will be provided in Section 2.1.

  • •

    Online optimization: Following the principle of OL, the objective of OFL is to learn a sequence of global models 𝐰1,𝐰2,…,𝐰Tsubscript𝐰1subscript𝐰2…subscript𝐰𝑇{\bf w}_{1},{\bf w}_{2},...,{\bf w}_{T} in an online fashion such that the so-called cumulative regret is minimized (see Section 2.2).

Remarkably, due to the aforementioned differences, it is required to conduct a new theoretical analysis for OFL, even if similar techniques in FL are applied.

2.1 Sequential Data Acquisition

We consider a distributed learning framework consisting of K𝐾K clients indexed by k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K] and a central server. At time step t𝑡t, the central server broadcasts the up-to-date global model (denoted by 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡{\bf w}_{t}) to the K𝐾K clients. Accordingly, our learned function at the current time step is defined as f​(𝐱;𝐰t)𝑓𝐱subscript𝐰𝑡f({\bf x};{{\bf w}}_{t}), from which every client k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K] can estimate the label of newly incoming (previously unseen) feature data 𝐱k,t∈𝒳⊆ℝNsubscript𝐱𝑘𝑡𝒳superscriptℝ𝑁{\bf x}_{k,t}\in\mathcal{X}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{N} in real time. We next focus on the local operations which are performed in a distributed way. At time step t𝑡t, each client k∈[k]𝑘delimited-[]𝑘k\in[k] starts to update its local model once it receives the true label of 𝐱k,tsubscript𝐱𝑘𝑡{\bf x}_{k,t}, denoted by yk,t∈𝒴⊆ℝsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑡𝒴ℝy_{k,t}\in\mathcal{Y}\subseteq\mathbb{R}. Given the labeled data (𝐱k,t,yk,t)subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡({\bf x}_{k,t},y_{k,t}) and the latest global model 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡{\bf w}_{t}, the client k𝑘k optimizes the local model (denoted as 𝐦k,t∈ℝDsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑡superscriptℝ𝐷{\bf m}_{k,t}\in\mathbb{R}^{D}) and sends it back to the central server. From the aggregated local models {𝐦k,t:k∈[K]}conditional-setsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑡𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\{{\bf m}_{k,t}:k\in[K]\}, the central server constructs an updated global model by simply averaging them:

𝐰t+1=1K​∑k=1K𝐦k,t,subscript𝐰𝑡11𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐦𝑘𝑡\displaystyle{{\bf w}}_{t+1}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}{\bf m}_{k,t}, (2)

and then broadcasts it back to the K𝐾K clients.

Communication costs (per time step): The communication costs of an OFL method are measured by the number of total transmitted bits of local information (e.g., 𝐦k,tsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑡{\bf m}_{k,t}’s) conveyed from the K𝐾K clients to the central server (in short, uplink communication costs). For instance, if every client sends a D𝐷D-dimensional real-valued vector (i.e., 𝐦k,t∈ℝDsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑡superscriptℝ𝐷{\bf m}_{k,t}\in\mbox{\bb R}^{D}) to the central server, the corresponding communication costs are equal to 32​K​D32𝐾𝐷32KD bits. Herein, 32-bit quantization is typically assumed to represent a real-value precisely. The communication costs from the central server to the K𝐾K clients (i.e., downlink communication costs) are not of concern as they are relatively very small due to the broadcasting nature.

2.2 Online Optimization

We describe an OFL protocol focusing on the ML optimization of a sequence of global models. At every time step t=1,2,…,T𝑡12…𝑇t=1,2,...,T:

  • •

    A global model 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡{\bf w}_{t} is updated by averaging the aggregated local models {𝐦k,t−1:k∈[K]}conditional-setsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑡1𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\{{\bf m}_{k,t-1}:k\in[K]\}.

  • •

    Simultaneously a new local data (𝐱k,t,yk,t)subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡({\bf x}_{k,t},y_{k,t}) is generated at each client k𝑘k for ∀k∈[K]for-all𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\forall k\in[K].

  • •

    Each client k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K] suffers from the local loss ℒ​(f​(𝐱k,t;𝐰t),yk,t)ℒ𝑓subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡subscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡{\cal L}(f({\bf x}_{k,t};{\bf w}_{t}),y_{k,t}), where ℒ​(⋅,⋅)ℒ⋅⋅{\cal L}(\cdot,\cdot) is a loss (or cost) function that measures the error between true and predicted labels.

  • •

    Leveraging the local-loss, each client k𝑘k optimizes its local model 𝐦k,tsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑡{\bf m}_{k,t}.

As in (centralized) OL [25, 22, 27, 21], the objective of OFL is to seek a sequence of global models 𝐰1,𝐰2,…,𝐰Tsubscript𝐰1subscript𝐰2…subscript𝐰𝑇{\bf w}_{1},{\bf w}_{2},...,{\bf w}_{T} that minimizes the cumulative regret over T𝑇T time steps:

regretTsubscriptregret𝑇\displaystyle{\rm regret}_{T} =∑t=1T∑k=1Kℒ​(f​(𝐱k,t;𝐰t),yk,t)absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾ℒ𝑓subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡subscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡\displaystyle=\sum_{t=1}^{T}\sum_{k=1}^{K}{\cal L}({f}({\bf x}_{k,t};{{\bf w}}_{t}),y_{k,t})
−min𝐰∈ℝD​∑t=1T∑k=1Kℒ​(f​(𝐱k,t;𝐰),yk,t).subscript𝐰superscriptℝ𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾ℒ𝑓subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡𝐰subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡\displaystyle\quad\quad\quad-\min_{{\bf w}\in\mbox{\bb R}^{D}}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\sum_{k=1}^{K}{\cal L}(f({\bf x}_{k,t};{\bf w}),y_{k,t}). (3)

The upper bound on regretTsubscriptregret𝑇\mbox{regret}_{T} is referred to as regret bound. This metric compares the cumulative loss of an OFL method with that of the static optimal function in hindsight. We emphasize that due to the sequential optimization nature of OFL protocol, its performance metric in (3) becomes totally different from that of (conventional) FL methods. To be specific, the local steps of FL methods aim at optimizing an objective function such as the expected global loss over local data distributions, whereas those of OFL methods aim at minimizing the cumulative regret in (3). Therefore, it is required to conduct a new analysis for OFL methods even if they are constructed using the well-proven techniques in the existing FL methods. We contribute to this subject.

3 Methods

In this section, we introduce a vanilla method for OFL as the counterpart of FedSGD for FL, and then improve its communication-efficiency by means of intermittent transmission and quantization.

3.1 Vanilla Method: FedOGD

We construct a vanilla method by integrating online gradient descent (OGD) [25] into OFL. This method is named FedOGD (i.e., the de facto algorithm in OFL) as the counterpart of FedSGD in FL [6]. To learn a sequence of global models in an online fashion, at every time step t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T], FedOGD consists of the following two steps (see Algorithm 1):

i) Local update: At time step t𝑡t, each client k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K] is aware of a current global model 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡{{\bf w}}_{t} (which is conveyed from the central server at time step t−1𝑡1t-1) and receives an incoming data (𝐱k,t,yk,t)subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡({\bf x}_{k,t},y_{k,t}). Leveraging them, it optimizes the local model via OGD [25]:

𝐰k,t+1=𝐰t−η​∇ℒ​(f​(𝐱k,t;𝐰t),yk,t),subscript𝐰𝑘𝑡1subscript𝐰𝑡𝜂∇ℒ𝑓subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡subscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡{{\bf w}}_{k,t+1}={{\bf w}}_{t}-\eta\nabla{\cal L}\left(f({\bf x}_{k,t};{{\bf w}}_{t}),y_{k,t}\right), (4)

with a step size (or learning rate) η>0𝜂0\eta>0 and the initial value 𝐰1subscript𝐰1{{\bf w}}_{1}, where ∇ℒ​(f​(𝐱k,t;𝐰t),yk,t)∇ℒ𝑓subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡subscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡\nabla{\cal L}\left(f({\bf x}_{k,t};{{\bf w}}_{t}),y_{k,t}\right) is the gradient at the point 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡{{\bf w}}_{t}. Then, every client k𝑘k sends the updated local model 𝐦k,t=𝐰k,t+1∈ℝDsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑡subscript𝐰𝑘𝑡1superscriptℝ𝐷{\bf m}_{k,t}={{\bf w}}_{k,t+1}\in\mbox{\bb R}^{D} back to the central server. The communication costs of FedOGD are equal to 32​D​K32𝐷𝐾32DK bits.

ii) Global update: From the aggregated local models {𝐦k,t=𝐰k,t+1:k∈[K]}conditional-setsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑡subscript𝐰𝑘𝑡1𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\{{\bf m}_{k,t}={{\bf w}}_{k,t+1}:k\in[K]\}, the central server constructs a global model via averaging:

𝐰t+1subscript𝐰𝑡1\displaystyle{{\bf w}}_{t+1} =1K​∑k=1K𝐦[k,t]absent1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐦𝑘𝑡\displaystyle=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}{{\bf m}}_{[k,t]}
=𝐰t−ηK​∑k=1K∇ℒ​(f​(𝐱k,t;𝐰t),yk,t).absentsubscript𝐰𝑡𝜂𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾∇ℒ𝑓subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡subscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡\displaystyle={\bf w}_{t}-\frac{\eta}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\nabla{\cal L}\left(f({\bf x}_{k,t};{{\bf w}}_{t}),y_{k,t}\right). (5)

Then, it broadcasts the updated global model 𝐰t+1∈ℝDsubscript𝐰𝑡1superscriptℝ𝐷{{\bf w}}_{t+1}\in\mbox{\bb R}^{D} to all K𝐾K clients.

3.2 Communication-Efficient Method: OFedIQ

To alleviate the heavy communication costs, numerous communication-reduction techniques have been proposed for conventional FL [11, 12, 13, 14]. Among them, the key features can be summarized as follows: (i) client subsampling (a.k.a. partial client participation); ii) periodic transmission (a.k.a. periodic averaging); (iii) quantization. Note that (i) and (ii) enable intermittent transmission, thereby directly reducing the number of transmissions, and (iii) decreases the number of transmitted bits per communication-channel. We first describe the three key features in the context of OFL (see Fig. 1).

Client subsampling: In OFL, there are lots of clients (e.g., smart phone users) communicating with a central server via an uplink communication channel. At every time step, thus, it is impractical to have all clients participating in OFL protocol due to the extremely heavy communication costs. As in (conventional) FL methods [6, 11], client subsampling, where a small fraction of clients are participated in OFL protocol at every time step, is necessary for OFL methods. To that end, we in this paper adopt the probabilistic client subsampling: each client k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K] can be sampled (or participated) with probability 0<pk<10subscript𝑝𝑘10<p_{k}<1 independently at every time step and from other clients, where pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k} indicates the sampling rate (or participation probability). Note that various pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k}’s can take into account system-heterogeneity since higher probabilities can be assigned to the clients with higher computation capabilities or communication capacities. We remark that this probabilistic approach is required for the compactness of tighter regret analysis while any approach can be immediately applied to the proposed OFL method. Throughout the paper, 𝒮t⊆[K]subscript𝒮𝑡delimited-[]𝐾{\cal S}_{t}\subseteq[K] represents the index subset of participating (or sampled) clients at time step t𝑡t. In convention, full client participation implies that pk=1subscript𝑝𝑘1p_{k}=1 for ∀k∈[K]for-all𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\forall k\in[K] (i.e., 𝒮t=[K]subscript𝒮𝑡delimited-[]𝐾{\cal S}_{t}=[K] for ∀tfor-all𝑡\forall t). Obviously, when pk<1subscript𝑝𝑘1p_{k}<1 for some k𝑘k, 𝒮t⊆[K]subscript𝒮𝑡delimited-[]𝐾{\cal S}_{t}\subseteq[K] is a random variable due to our probabilistic modeling, namely, a time-varying client subsampling is considered. When our client subsampling is applied, the communication cost can be reduced to 32​D​∑k=1Kpk32𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑘32D\sum_{k=1}^{K}p_{k} bits in average. In the homogeneous setting with pk=psubscript𝑝𝑘𝑝p_{k}=p for ∀kfor-all𝑘\forall k, they can be simplified as 32​p​K​D32𝑝𝐾𝐷32pKD bits in average

Periodic transmission: Periodic transmission is one of the key techniques to reduce the communication costs in FL [11]. However, in OFL, this method might degrade the performance (i.e., the cumulative regret in (3)) as a new global model 𝐰t+1subscript𝐰𝑡1{\bf w}_{t+1} should be constructed at every time step. This question will be addressed in Section 4 based on our tighter regret analysis. Assuming the transmission period L≥1𝐿1L\geq 1, each client k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K] sends the local information 𝐦k,tsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑡{\bf m}_{k,t} to the central server at every L𝐿L time steps. Due to the infrequent transmission, a sequence of learned global models is obtained as

𝐰1→⋯→𝐰1⏟L→𝐰L+1→⋯→𝐰L+1⏟L→𝐰2​L+1​⋯.→subscript⏟→subscript𝐰1⋯→subscript𝐰1𝐿subscript⏟→subscript𝐰𝐿1⋯→subscript𝐰𝐿1𝐿→subscript𝐰2𝐿1⋯\underbrace{{\bf w}_{1}\rightarrow\cdots\rightarrow{\bf w}_{1}}_{L}\rightarrow\underbrace{{\bf w}_{L+1}\rightarrow\cdots\rightarrow{\bf w}_{L+1}}_{L}\rightarrow{\bf w}_{2L+1}\cdots.

Thus, for some positive integer a𝑎a, each client k𝑘k estimates the label of newly incoming data at time step t∈[a​L+1,(a+1)​L+1)𝑡𝑎𝐿1𝑎1𝐿1t\in[aL+1,(a+1)L+1) such as

y^k,t=f​(𝐱k,t;𝐰a​L+1).subscript^𝑦𝑘𝑡𝑓subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡subscript𝐰𝑎𝐿1\hat{y}_{k,t}=f({\bf x}_{k,t};{\bf w}_{aL+1}).

For example, during the L𝐿L time steps 2​L+1≤t≤3​L2𝐿1𝑡3𝐿2L+1\leq t\leq 3L, the identical global model 𝐰2​L+1subscript𝐰2𝐿1{\bf w}_{2L+1} (which is updated at time 2​L2𝐿2L) is used. Generally, for any time step t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T], the corresponding global model is equal to 𝐰ψL​(t)subscript𝐰subscript𝜓𝐿𝑡{\bf w}_{\psi_{L}(t)}. While the communication costs are reduced to 32​K​D/L32𝐾𝐷𝐿32KD/L, the use of outdated global model might degrade learning accuracy. Thus, the transmission period L𝐿L should be carefully determined by considering the tradeoff between learning accuracy and communication overhead. On the basis of our analysis, we will give the answer to this question in Section 4.2.1.

Quantization: To reduce the communication costs, it is crucial to decrease the number of transmitted bits for conveying the local information 𝐦k,tsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑡{\bf m}_{k,t}’s. This can be done from the quantization of the information 𝐦k,tsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑡{\bf m}_{k,t} [11, 12, 13, 14]. In this paper, a q𝑞q-bit quantizer Qq​(⋅)subscript𝑄q⋅Q_{\rm q}(\cdot) is assumed. Note that any scalar or vector quantizer can be applied to the proposed OFL method. For our analysis and experiments, a specific quantizer will be defined.

Incorporating the aforementioned techniques into FedOGD, we present a communication-efficient OFL method, named Online Federated learning with Intermittent transmission and Quantization (OFedIQ). The proposed method performs with the following two steps (see Fig. 1):

i) Local update: At time step t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T], each client k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K] optimizes the local model by leveraging the incoming data (𝐱k,t,yk,t)subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡({\bf x}_{k,t},y_{k,t}) and the up-to-date global model. First, according to the time step t𝑡t, the parameter of a local function is updated via either globally or locally:

𝐠k,t={𝐰t,t−1∈[T]L𝜽k,t,elsesubscript𝐠𝑘𝑡casessubscript𝐰𝑡𝑡1subscriptdelimited-[]𝑇𝐿otherwisesubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡elseotherwise{\bf g}_{k,t}=\begin{cases}{\bf w}_{t},\;t-1\in[T]_{L}\\ \hbox{\boldmath$\theta$}_{k,t},\;\mbox{else}\end{cases} (6)

with initial values 𝐰1subscript𝐰1{\bf w}_{1} and 𝜽k,1subscript𝜽𝑘1\hbox{\boldmath$\theta$}_{k,1} for ∀k∈[K]for-all𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\forall k\in[K]. Using the incoming data, the local model is updated via OGD:

𝜽k,t+1=𝐠k,t−η​∇ℒ​(f​(𝐱k,t;𝐠k,t),yk,t),subscript𝜽𝑘𝑡1subscript𝐠𝑘𝑡𝜂∇ℒ𝑓subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡subscript𝐠𝑘𝑡subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡\hbox{\boldmath$\theta$}_{k,t+1}={\bf g}_{k,t}-\eta\nabla{\cal L}(f({\bf x}_{k,t};{\bf g}_{k,t}),y_{k,t}), (7)

where η>0𝜂0\eta>0 is a learning rate.

Due to the use of periodic transmission, at every L𝐿L time steps (i.e., when t∈[T]L⊂[T]𝑡subscriptdelimited-[]𝑇𝐿delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T]_{L}\subset[T]), each client k𝑘k constructs the quantized and weighted local information 𝐦k,tsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑡{\bf m}_{k,t} such as

𝐦k,tsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑡\displaystyle{\bf m}_{k,t} =Qq​(−𝜽k,t+1−𝐠k,t−L+1η×pk)absentsubscript𝑄qsubscript𝜽𝑘𝑡1subscript𝐠𝑘𝑡𝐿1𝜂subscript𝑝𝑘\displaystyle=Q_{\rm q}\left(-\frac{\hbox{\boldmath$\theta$}_{k,t+1}-{\bf g}_{k,t-L+1}}{\eta\times p_{k}}\right) (8)
=Qq​(∑ℓ=1L∇ℒ​(f​(𝐱k,t−L+ℓ;𝐠k,t−L+ℓ),yk,t−L+ℓ)pk).absentsubscript𝑄qsuperscriptsubscriptℓ1𝐿∇ℒ𝑓subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡𝐿ℓsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑡𝐿ℓsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑡𝐿ℓsubscript𝑝𝑘\displaystyle=Q_{\rm q}\left(\sum_{\ell=1}^{L}\frac{\nabla{\cal L}(f({\bf x}_{k,t-L+\ell};{\bf g}_{k,t-L+\ell}),y_{k,t-L+\ell})}{p_{k}}\right).

Moreover, via client subsampling, every client k𝑘k can have a chance to participate in the global update with probability pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k}. That is, at every L𝐿L time step, each client k𝑘k can send the local information 𝐦k,tsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑡{\bf m}_{k,t} to the central server with probability pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k}.

ii) Global update: This step is conducted periodically only when t∈[T]L𝑡subscriptdelimited-[]𝑇𝐿t\in[T]_{L}. Let 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡{\cal S}_{t} denote the index subset of participating (or sampled) clients at time step t𝑡t. Using the received information {𝐦k,t:k∈𝒮t}conditional-setsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑡𝑘subscript𝒮𝑡\{{\bf m}_{k,t}:k\in{\cal S}_{t}\}, at each time step t∈[T]L𝑡subscriptdelimited-[]𝑇𝐿t\in[T]_{L}, the central server constructs the global parameter 𝐰t+1subscript𝐰𝑡1{\bf w}_{t+1} by simply averaging them:

𝐰t+1subscript𝐰𝑡1\displaystyle{\bf w}_{t+1} =𝐰t−L+1−ηK​∑k∈𝒮t𝐦k,tabsentsubscript𝐰𝑡𝐿1𝜂𝐾subscript𝑘subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝐦𝑘𝑡\displaystyle={\bf w}_{t-L+1}-\frac{\eta}{K}\sum_{k\in{\cal S}_{t}}{\bf m}_{k,t}
=𝐰t−L+1−ηK​∑k=1K𝟙{k∈𝒮t}​𝐦k,t,absentsubscript𝐰𝑡𝐿1𝜂𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript1𝑘subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝐦𝑘𝑡\displaystyle={\bf w}_{t-L+1}-\frac{\eta}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbbm{1}_{\{k\in{\cal S}_{t}\}}{\bf m}_{k,t}, (9)

where 𝟙{k∈𝒮t}subscript1𝑘subscript𝒮𝑡\mathbbm{1}_{\{k\in{\cal S}_{t}\}} stands for an indicator function having 111 if the client k𝑘k participates in the global update at time t𝑡t (i.e., k∈𝒮t𝑘subscript𝒮𝑡k\in{\cal S}_{t}). Then, the central server broadcasts the updated global model 𝐰t+1subscript𝐰𝑡1{\bf w}_{t+1} to all K𝐾K clients. We notice that the central server can perform the averaging operation in (9) without the knowledge of 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡{\cal S}_{t}, namely, it simply adds up all the received local information. The overall procedures are summarized in Algorithm 2.

Recall that the communication costs of the vanilla method (FedOGD) are equal to 32​K​D32𝐾𝐷32KD bits. Whereas, the communication costs of OFedIQ are reduced to p​K​D​log⁡(q)/L𝑝𝐾𝐷𝑞𝐿pKD\log{(q)}/L bits. On the basis of our regret analysis, the parameters p𝑝p, L𝐿L, and q𝑞q will be efficiently optimized in Section 4.2.

4 Regret Analysis

In this section, we conduct a tighter regret analysis for OFL methods in Section 3.2. Our analysis is non-trivial extensions of the existing ones such as the centralized OL [22, 26, 27] and decentralized OL [27, 28, 21, 29, 24]. For the first time, our regret bound can reflect the impact of data-heterogeneity and the key communication-reduction techniques such as client subsampling, periodic transmission, and quantization. Contrary to the existing OL analyses [22, 26, 29, 27, 28, 21], we do not assume the bounded gradient (a.k.a. G𝐺G-Lipschitz continuous) such as ‖∇ℒ​(f​(𝐱k,t;𝐰),yk,t)‖2≤Gsuperscriptnorm∇ℒ𝑓subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡𝐰subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡2𝐺\|\nabla{\cal L}(f({\bf x}_{k,t};{\bf w}),y_{k,t})\|^{2}\leq G for any 𝐰,k∈[K],t∈[T]formulae-sequence𝐰𝑘delimited-[]𝐾𝑡delimited-[]𝑇{\bf w},k\in[K],t\in[T]. As identified in SGD analysis of FL [10], this assumption makes the OL analysis simple but it can ignore the effect of data-heterogeneity. Instead, we introduce a more meaningful quantity (defined by σdiff2superscriptsubscript𝜎diff2\sigma_{\rm diff}^{2} in Definition 1), which can capture the degree of data-heterogeneity over time and across decentralized clients. Based on our tighter regret analysis, we theoretically prove that OFedIQ over T𝑇T time steps can achieve an optimal subliner regret 𝒪​(α​T)𝒪𝛼𝑇{\cal O}(\sqrt{\alpha T})) for any dataset, wherein the constant α>0𝛼0\alpha>0 relies on the degree of data-heterogeneity and the key parameters of the communication-reduction techniques (see Theorem 1 and Theorem 2). As expected, α𝛼\alpha tends to be bigger as data-heterogeneity (i.e., σdiff2superscriptsubscript𝜎diff2\sigma_{\rm diff}^{2}) grows. More importantly, our regret bound enables to optimize the key parameters of OFedIQ such as sampling rate, transmission period, and quantization levels (see Section 4.2).

Before stating the main results, we provide some useful notations and definitions. Let 𝐰⋆subscript𝐰⋆{\bf w}_{\star} be the parameter of the best function in hindsight, i.e.,

𝐰⋆=Δargmin𝐰∈ℝD​∑t=1T∑k=1Kℒ​(f​(𝐱k,t;𝐰),yk,t).superscriptΔsubscript𝐰⋆subscriptargmin𝐰superscriptℝ𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾ℒ𝑓subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡𝐰subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡{\bf w}_{\star}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\operatornamewithlimits{argmin}_{{\bf w}\in\mbox{\bb R}^{D}}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\sum_{k=1}^{K}{\cal L}(f({\bf x}_{k,t};{\bf w}),y_{k,t}). (10)

Recall that {𝐰t+1:t∈[T]L}conditional-setsubscript𝐰𝑡1𝑡subscriptdelimited-[]𝑇𝐿\{{\bf w}_{t+1}:t\in[T]_{L}\} is the sequence of outputs provided by Algorithm 2 and accordingly, from the notation in (1), 𝐰ψL​(t)subscript𝐰subscript𝜓𝐿𝑡{\bf w}_{\psi_{L}(t)} is the common global model for t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T]. For ease of exposition, let 𝔼[⋅|𝐰(⌊(t−1)/L⌋−1)⋅L+1]=Δ𝔼t[⋅]\mbox{\bb E}[\cdot|{\bf w}_{(\lfloor(t-1)/L\rfloor-1)\cdot L+1}]\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\mbox{\bb E}_{t}[\cdot] be the conditional expectation at time step t𝑡t given the latest global model. Also, we let

pminsubscript𝑝min\displaystyle p_{\rm min} =Δmin⁡{p1,p2,…,pK}​ and ​psum=Δ∑k=1Kpk,superscriptΔabsentsubscript𝑝1subscript𝑝2…subscript𝑝𝐾 and subscript𝑝sumsuperscriptΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑘\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\min\{p_{1},p_{2},...,p_{K}\}\mbox{ and }p_{\rm sum}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\sum_{k=1}^{K}p_{k},

where pminsubscript𝑝minp_{\rm min} can capture the effect of the slowest client (e.g., straggler), and psum​Ksubscript𝑝sum𝐾p_{\rm sum}K denotes the number of clients (in average) that participates in a global model update at every time step. Extending the idea in [10] into OFL setting having no statistical assumption on data, we have:

Definition 1

Given decentralized streaming data {(𝐱k,t,yk,t):t∈[T],k∈[K]}conditional-setsubscript𝐱𝑘𝑡subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡formulae-sequence𝑡delimited-[]𝑇𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\{({\bf x}_{k,t},y_{k,t}):t\in[T],k\in[K]\}, we define the measure of variance at the optimum:

σdiff2=Δ1K​∑k=1K[1T​∑t=1T‖∇ℒ​(f​(𝐱k,t;𝐰⋆),yk,t)‖2],superscriptΔsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2diff1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾delimited-[]1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscriptnorm∇ℒ𝑓subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡subscript𝐰⋆subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡2\displaystyle\sigma^{2}_{\rm diff}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left[\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\left\|\nabla{\cal L}(f({\bf x}_{k,t};{\bf w}_{\star}),y_{k,t})\right\|^{2}\right],

where 𝐰⋆subscript𝐰⋆{\bf w}_{\star} is defined in (10).

This quantity reflects the degree of data-heterogeneity (or environmental dynamics in data acquisitions) in both temporal (i.e., over time) and geographical (i.e., across decentralized clients).

4.1 Main Results

For our analysis, we make the following assumptions, which are commonly assumed for the analysis of online convex optimization and online learning.

Assumption 1. For any fixed (𝐱k,t,yk,t)subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡({\bf x}_{k,t},y_{k,t}), the loss function ℒ​(f​(𝐱k,t;𝐰),yk,t)ℒ𝑓subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡𝐰subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡{\cal L}(f({\bf x}_{k,t};{\bf w}),y_{k,t}) is convex with respect to 𝐰𝐰{\bf w} and differentiable.

Assumption 2. For any fixed (𝐱k,t,yk,t)subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡({\bf x}_{k,t},y_{k,t}), the loss function ℒ​(f​(𝐱k,t;𝐰),yk,t)ℒ𝑓subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡𝐰subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡{\cal L}(f({\bf x}_{k,t};{\bf w}),y_{k,t}) is β𝛽\beta-smooth.

We state the main results of this section.

Theorem 1

Under Assumption 1 and Assumption 2, OFedAvg with η<pmin2​β𝜂subscript𝑝min2𝛽\eta<\frac{p_{\rm min}}{2\beta} (i.e., L=1𝐿1L=1 and no quantization), achieves the following regret bound:

From Theorem 1 and the regret bound of OGD in [22, 27], we obtain:

ΔF−CsubscriptΔFC\displaystyle\Delta_{\rm F-C} =LFedOGD−LOGDabsentsubscript𝐿FedOGDsubscript𝐿OGD\displaystyle=L_{\rm FedOGD}-L_{\rm OGD}

where LFedOGDsubscript𝐿FedOGDL_{\rm FedOGD} and LOGDsubscript𝐿OGDL_{\rm OGD} denote the average cumulative losses of FedOGD and OGD, respectively. This gap reveals the performance loss caused by distributed learning under OL framework. As K𝐾K grows, the gap becomes larger but it is bounded as

ΔF−C≤2​‖𝐰⋆‖2​σdiff2T.subscriptΔFC2superscriptnormsubscript𝐰⋆2superscriptsubscript𝜎diff2𝑇\Delta_{\rm F-C}\leq\sqrt{\frac{2\|{\bf w}_{\star}\|^{2}\sigma_{\rm diff}^{2}}{T}}. (11)

For a sufficiently large T𝑇T, FedOGD can achieve the performance of the centralized OGD while preserving local data-privacy.

We next investigate if OFedIQ still guarantees the asymptotic optimality while reducing the communication costs of FedOGD. Toward this, we derive the regret bound of OFedIQ under the stochastic quantization below.

The proof is provided in Section 4.3.2. ∎

Note that when quantization and periodic transmission are not used (i.e., σq2=0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑞20\sigma_{q}^{2}=0 and L=1𝐿1L=1), the regret bound in Theorem 2 is not exactly matched with that in Theorem 1 although in this case, OFedIQ is reduced to OFedAvg. Specifically, there is the difference in the second term by the factor of 2. In fact, this is due to the mathematical artifact in our bounding technique to deal with quantized gradients. Thus, the regret bound of OFedIQ with no quantization is obtained from Theorem 2 with σq2=0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑞20\sigma_{q}^{2}=0 and by removing the constant 2 in the second term.

4.2 Optimization of OFedIQ

Although the asymptotic optimality of OFedIQ is proved, it does not ensure the best performances of OFedIQ for real-world OFL tasks. Thus, on the basis of our regret analysis in Section 4.1, we further optimize the parameters of OFedIQ in Algorithm 2 such as sampling rate, transmission period, and quantization parameters. First we introduce a stochastic quantizer that will be used for our experiments in Section 5. This is an extension of the widely-used stochastic quantizer in [30, 11] by introducing the new parameter b𝑏b (see Definition 2 for details), where the proposed quantizer with b=1𝑏1b=1 is reduced to the existing one in [30, 11]. With the optimized parameters, it will be shown that the proposed quantizer in Definition 2 can attain a non-trivial gain compared with the existing one.

Definition 2

(s,b)𝑠𝑏(s,b)-stochastic quantizer Qs,b​(⋅)subscript𝑄𝑠𝑏⋅Q_{s,b}(\cdot): For any positive integer b𝑏b, let ℐ1,ℐ2,…,ℐbsubscriptℐ1subscriptℐ2…subscriptℐ𝑏{\cal I}_{1},{\cal I}_{2},...,{\cal I}_{b} be the partition of the indices of the vector 𝐮∈ℝD𝐮superscriptℝ𝐷{\bf u}\in\mbox{\bb R}^{D} (i.e., the partition of [D]delimited-[]𝐷[D]) such that

ℐℓ=Δ{∑τ=1ℓ−1|ℐτ|+1,….,∑τ=1ℓ|ℐτ|}.{\cal I}_{\ell}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\left\{\sum_{\tau=1}^{\ell-1}|{\cal I}_{\tau}|+1,....,\sum_{\tau=1}^{\ell}|{\cal I}_{\tau}|\right\}.

Note that in our experiments, the uniform-size partition is considered, i.e., |ℐℓ|≈Dbsubscriptℐℓ𝐷𝑏|{\cal I}_{\ell}|\approx\frac{D}{b} for ∀ℓ∈[b]for-allℓdelimited-[]𝑏\forall\ell\in[b]. Given a vector 𝐮∈ℝD𝐮superscriptℝ𝐷{\bf u}\in\mbox{\bb R}^{D}, let 𝐮ℐℓsubscript𝐮subscriptℐℓ{\bf u}_{{\cal I}_{\ell}} be the subvector of 𝐮𝐮{\bf u}, which is formed by taking the entries of 𝐮𝐮{\bf u} whose indices belong to ℐℓsubscriptℐℓ{\cal I}_{\ell}. For any 𝐮∈ℝD𝐮superscriptℝ𝐷{\bf u}\in\mbox{\bb R}^{D}, stochastic quantizer Qs,b:ℝD→ℝD:subscript𝑄𝑠𝑏→superscriptℝ𝐷superscriptℝ𝐷Q_{s,b}:\mbox{\bb R}^{D}\rightarrow\mbox{\bb R}^{D} is defined as

(Qs,b​(𝐮))i=‖𝐮ℐℓ‖⋅𝐬𝐢𝐠𝐧​(𝐮i)⋅ξi​(𝐮,s),subscriptsubscript𝑄𝑠𝑏𝐮𝑖⋅⋅normsubscript𝐮subscriptℐℓ𝐬𝐢𝐠𝐧subscript𝐮𝑖subscript𝜉𝑖𝐮𝑠\left(Q_{s,b}({\bf u})\right)_{i}=\|{\bf u}_{{\cal I}_{\ell}}\|\cdot\mathbf{sign}({\bf u}_{i})\cdot\xi_{i}({\bf u},s), (12)

The parameters s𝑠s and b𝑏b denote the quantization-level for each entry of 𝐮𝐮{\bf u} and the number of partitions to indicate magnitudes, respectively. Note that when b=1𝑏1b=1, this quantizer is reduced to the s𝑠s-level stochastic quantizer introduced in [11]. 4.2.1 Needlessness of periodic transmission

Consider the two OFedIQs having the same communication costs such as OFedIQ(L,p,s,b)𝐿𝑝𝑠𝑏(L,p,s,b) and OFedIQ(L=1,p′=p/L,s,b)formulae-sequence𝐿1superscript𝑝′𝑝𝐿𝑠𝑏(L=1,p^{\prime}=p/L,s,b). Leveraging the regret bounds in Table 1, we can identify that the latter outperforms the former as follows:

1+D/s2​b​(p′+1/K)p′=1+D/s2​b​(p/L+1/K)p/L1𝐷superscript𝑠2𝑏superscript𝑝′1𝐾superscript𝑝′1𝐷superscript𝑠2𝑏𝑝𝐿1𝐾𝑝𝐿\displaystyle\frac{1+\sqrt{D/s^{2}b}(p^{\prime}+1/K)}{p^{\prime}}=\frac{1+\sqrt{D/s^{2}b}(p/L+1/K)}{p/L}
≤3​p2​(L−1)/8+1+D/s2​b​(p+1/K)p/L,absent3superscript𝑝2𝐿181𝐷superscript𝑠2𝑏𝑝1𝐾𝑝𝐿\displaystyle\quad\quad\leq\frac{3p^{2}(L-1)/8+1+\sqrt{D/s^{2}b}(p+1/K)}{p/L},

where the equality holds with L=1𝐿1L=1. This analysis shows that in OFL, client subsampling is sufficient for intermittent transmission, namely, periodic transmission is unnecessary. Thus, L=1𝐿1L=1 is the best choice for OFedIQ. In the subsequent subsection, we will optimize the remaining parameters p𝑝p and (s,b)𝑠𝑏(s,b) of OFedIQ.

4.3 Proof of Main Theorems

We prove the regret bounds in Theorem 1 and Theorem 2. To simplify the expressions in the proofs, we let

∇k,t(𝐰)=Δ∇ℒ​(f​(𝐱k,t;𝐰),yk,t),superscriptΔsubscript∇𝑘𝑡𝐰∇ℒ𝑓subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡𝐰subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡\nabla_{k,t}({\bf w})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\nabla{\cal L}\left(f({\bf x}_{k,t};{{\bf w}}),y_{k,t}\right), (21)

for any vector 𝐰∈ℝD𝐰superscriptℝ𝐷{\bf w}\in\mbox{\bb R}^{D}. We first provide the supporting lemmas (Lemma 1 and Lemma 2) for the proofs.

Lemma 1

Letting 𝐯i,𝐯j∈ℝdsubscript𝐯𝑖subscript𝐯𝑗superscriptℝ𝑑{\bf v}_{i},{\bf v}_{j}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and for any a>0𝑎0a>0, the following inequality holds:

‖𝐯i+𝐯j‖2≤(1+a)​‖𝐯i‖2+(1+1/a)​‖𝐯j‖2.superscriptnormsubscript𝐯𝑖subscript𝐯𝑗21𝑎superscriptnormsubscript𝐯𝑖211𝑎superscriptnormsubscript𝐯𝑗2\displaystyle\|{\bf v}_{i}+{\bf v}_{j}\|^{2}\leq(1+a)\|{\bf v}_{i}\|^{2}+\left(1+1/a\right)\|{\bf v}_{j}\|^{2}.
Proof:

The proof is directly from the equality: ‖𝐯i+𝐯j‖2=(1+a)​‖𝐯i‖2+(1+1/a)​‖𝐯j‖2−‖a​𝐯i−𝐯j/a‖2superscriptnormsubscript𝐯𝑖subscript𝐯𝑗21𝑎superscriptnormsubscript𝐯𝑖211𝑎superscriptnormsubscript𝐯𝑗2superscriptnorm𝑎subscript𝐯𝑖subscript𝐯𝑗𝑎2\|{\bf v}_{i}+{\bf v}_{j}\|^{2}=(1+a)\|{\bf v}_{i}\|^{2}+\left(1+1/a\right)\|{\bf v}_{j}\|^{2}-\left\|\sqrt{a}{\bf v}_{i}-{\bf v}_{j}/\sqrt{a}\right\|^{2}. ∎

The following inequality holds:

Proof:

From Lemma 1 with a=1𝑎1a=1, we have:

4.3.2 Proof of Theorem 2

To clarify the proof, we first prove Theorem 2 in the special case of L=1𝐿1L=1 and then extend it to the general case of L>1𝐿1L>1.

(a) L=1𝐿1L=1. Given a quantizer Q​(⋅)𝑄⋅Q(\cdot), a quantized gradient is denoted as

∇^k,t​(𝐰t)=Q​(∇k,t(𝐰t)/pk).subscript^∇𝑘𝑡subscript𝐰𝑡𝑄subscript∇𝑘𝑡subscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝑝𝑘\hat{\nabla}_{k,t}({\bf w}_{t})=Q\left(\nabla_{k,t}({\bf w}_{t})/p_{k}\right).

where 𝟙{k∈𝒮}subscript1𝑘𝒮\mathbbm{1}_{\{k\in{\cal S}\}} is an indicator function having 111 if the client k𝑘k is active at time t𝑡t. As derived in (25), from (31) we derive the key inequality:

(b) L>1𝐿1L>1. We extend the above proof for the general case of L>1𝐿1L>1. The supporting lemmas (Lemma 3 and Lemma 4) are provided in the last part of this section. To concise the expressions and explain the key ides of our proof clearly, it is assumed that T𝑇T is a multiple of L𝐿L. In a general case, we need to take some exceptions for the few time indices ⌊T/L⌋⋅L+1,⌊T/L⌋⋅L+2,…,T⋅𝑇𝐿𝐿1⋅𝑇𝐿𝐿2…𝑇\lfloor T/L\rfloor\cdot L+1,\lfloor T/L\rfloor\cdot L+2,...,T. Clearly, the number of these extra-terms is less than L𝐿L. Thus, when T𝑇T is sufficiently large, the impact of exceptional terms can be negligible. ≤(c)3​η2​L​(L−1)​∑ℓ=1L‖∇k,t−L+ℓ‖2,superscript𝑐absent3superscript𝜂2𝐿𝐿1superscriptsubscriptℓ1𝐿superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑘𝑡𝐿ℓ2\displaystyle\quad\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(c)}}{{\leq}}3\eta^{2}L(L-1)\sum_{\ell=1}^{L}\|\nabla_{k,t-L+\ell}\|^{2}, (46)

where (a) is from Lemma 1 with a=1L−1𝑎1𝐿1a=\frac{1}{L-1}, (b)𝑏(b) is from Lemma 4, and (c) is due to the fact that

(1+1/(L−1))L−1≤limL→∞(1+1/(L−1))L−1=e<3,superscript11𝐿1𝐿1subscript→𝐿superscript11𝐿1𝐿1𝑒3\displaystyle\left(1+1/(L-1)\right)^{L-1}\leq\lim_{L\rightarrow\infty}\left(1+1/(L-1)\right)^{L-1}=e<3,

and for L>1𝐿1L>1,

∑ℓ=2L∑τ=0ℓ−2‖∇k,t−L+ℓ−1−τ‖2≤(L−1)​∑ℓ=1L‖∇k,t−L+ℓ‖2.superscriptsubscriptℓ2𝐿superscriptsubscript𝜏0ℓ2superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑘𝑡𝐿ℓ1𝜏2𝐿1superscriptsubscriptℓ1𝐿superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑘𝑡𝐿ℓ2\displaystyle\sum_{\ell=2}^{L}\sum_{\tau=0}^{\ell-2}\left\|\nabla_{k,t-L+\ell-1-\tau}\right\|^{2}\leq(L-1)\sum_{\ell=1}^{L}\|\nabla_{k,t-L+\ell}\|^{2}.

This completes the proof. ∎

Lemma 4

For ℓ≥2ℓ2\ell\geq 2, the following inequality holds:

A​‖𝐰t−𝐠k,t+ℓ−2‖2+B​‖∇k,t+ℓ−2‖2𝐴superscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝐠𝑘𝑡ℓ22𝐵superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑘𝑡ℓ22\displaystyle A\|{\bf w}_{t}-{\bf g}_{k,t+\ell-2}\|^{2}+B\|\nabla_{k,t+\ell-2}\|^{2}
≤∑τ=0ℓ−2B​‖∇k,t+ℓ−2−τ‖2​Aτ,absentsuperscriptsubscript𝜏0ℓ2𝐵superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑘𝑡ℓ2𝜏2superscript𝐴𝜏\displaystyle\leq\sum_{\tau=0}^{\ell-2}B\|\nabla_{k,t+\ell-2-\tau}\|^{2}A^{\tau}, (47)

where A=(1+1/(L−1))𝐴11𝐿1A=(1+1/(L-1)) and B=L​η2𝐵𝐿superscript𝜂2B=L\eta^{2}.

Proof:

The proof will be done by induction. When ℓ=2ℓ2\ell=2, the inequality in (47) is trivial because 𝐰t=𝐠k,tsubscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝐠𝑘𝑡{\bf w}_{t}={\bf g}_{k,t} and accordingly we have:

A​‖𝐰t−𝐠k,t‖2+B​‖∇k,t‖2=B​‖∇k,t‖2.𝐴superscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝐠𝑘𝑡2𝐵superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑘𝑡2𝐵superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑘𝑡2A\|{\bf w}_{t}-{\bf g}_{k,t}\|^{2}+B\|\nabla_{k,t}\|^{2}=B\|\nabla_{k,t}\|^{2}. (48)

Suppose that the inequality in (47) holds for 2≤m<ℓ2𝑚ℓ2\leq m<\ell, i.e.,

A​‖𝐰t−𝐠k,t+m−2‖2+B​‖∇k,t+m−2‖2𝐴superscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝐠𝑘𝑡𝑚22𝐵superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑘𝑡𝑚22\displaystyle A\|{\bf w}_{t}-{\bf g}_{k,t+m-2}\|^{2}+B\|\nabla_{k,t+m-2}\|^{2}
≤∑τ=0m−2B​‖∇k,t+m−2−τ‖2​Aτ.absentsuperscriptsubscript𝜏0𝑚2𝐵superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑘𝑡𝑚2𝜏2superscript𝐴𝜏\displaystyle\leq\sum_{\tau=0}^{m-2}B\|\nabla_{k,t+m-2-\tau}\|^{2}A^{\tau}. (49)

Focusing on m+1𝑚1m+1, then, we have:

A​‖𝐰t−𝐠k,t+m−1‖2+B​‖∇k,t+m−1‖2𝐴superscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝐠𝑘𝑡𝑚12𝐵superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑘𝑡𝑚12\displaystyle A\|{\bf w}_{t}-{\bf g}_{k,t+m-1}\|^{2}+B\|\nabla_{k,t+m-1}\|^{2}
≤(a)A​(A​‖𝐰t−𝐠k,t+m−2‖2+‖∇k,t+m−2‖2)superscript𝑎absent𝐴𝐴superscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝐠𝑘𝑡𝑚22superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑘𝑡𝑚22\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(a)}}{{\leq}}A\left(A\|{\bf w}_{t}-{\bf g}_{k,t+m-2}\|^{2}+\|\nabla_{k,t+m-2}\|^{2}\right)
+B​‖∇k,t+m−1‖2𝐵superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑘𝑡𝑚12\displaystyle\quad\quad+B\|\nabla_{k,t+m-1}\|^{2}
≤(b)A​(∑τ=0m−2B​‖∇k,t+m−2−τ‖2​Aτ)+B​‖∇k,t+m−1‖2superscript𝑏absent𝐴superscriptsubscript𝜏0𝑚2𝐵superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑘𝑡𝑚2𝜏2superscript𝐴𝜏𝐵superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑘𝑡𝑚12\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(b)}}{{\leq}}A\left(\sum_{\tau=0}^{m-2}B\|\nabla_{k,t+m-2-\tau}\|^{2}A^{\tau}\right)+B\|\nabla_{k,t+m-1}\|^{2}
=∑τ=0(m+1)−2B​‖∇k,t+(m+1)−2−τ‖2​Aτabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝜏0𝑚12𝐵superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑘𝑡𝑚12𝜏2superscript𝐴𝜏\displaystyle=\sum_{\tau=0}^{(m+1)-2}B\|\nabla_{k,t+(m+1)-2-\tau}\|^{2}A^{\tau}

where (a) is from Lemma 1 with a=1L−1𝑎1𝐿1a=\frac{1}{L-1} and (b) is due to the hypothesis assumption in (49). This completes the proof. ∎

5 Experiments

Via experiments with real datasets, we verify the analytical results in Section 4 and demonstrate the superiority of the optimized OFedIQ compared with the state-of-the-art OFL methods. Recall that using the stochastic quantizer in Definition 2, the proposed method is denoted by OFedIQ(L,p,s,b)𝐿𝑝𝑠𝑏(L,p,s,b), where L𝐿L is the transmission period, p𝑝p is the sampling rate, and (s,b)𝑠𝑏(s,b) is the parameter of the quantization. In convention, when quantization is not applied, it is denoted as OFedIQ(L,p,∞)𝐿𝑝(L,p,\infty). For comparison, the following benchmark methods are considered:

  • •

    FedOGD [21]: This is the counterpart of FedSGD in FL. It is considered as the performance-limit of communication-efficient OFL methods.

  • •

    OFedAvg(p𝑝p): This is the counterpart of FedAvg [6]. In this method, a smaller number of clients are participated at every time step (i.e., p​K𝑝𝐾pK in average).

  • •

    FedOMD(L𝐿L)[24]: This is the communication-efficient OFL method based on OMD and periodic transmission. In our experiments, a commonly adopted Euclidean distance is used as the underlying Bregman divergence of OMD.

To the best of our knowledge, there is no other OFL method with a performance guarantee. In fact, OFedIQ(L,p,s,b)𝐿𝑝𝑠𝑏(L,p,s,b) subsumes the benchmark methods as special cases. Nonetheless, it does not directly imply that OFedIQ can outperform them. Namely, the parameters should be optimized, which is efficiently performed via the proposed Algorithm 3 For a hyperparameter η𝜂\eta, it was proved in Section 4 that η=𝒪​(1/T)𝜂𝒪1𝑇\eta={\cal O}(1/\sqrt{T}) is asymptotically optimal for the proposed and benchmark methods. In practice, however, it is generally unavailable to see the end-point of continuous streaming data (i.e., T𝑇T) in advance. We set η=0.01𝜂0.01\eta=0.01 for all experiments, which is sufficient for their fair comparisons. Let y^k,τsubscript^𝑦𝑘𝜏\hat{y}_{k,\tau} and yk,τsubscript𝑦𝑘𝜏y_{k,\tau} denote a predicted label and a true label, respectively. As commonly adopted in online learning tasks [26, 27, 21], we use the following metric to assess learning accuracy:

  • •

    Online classifications:

    Accuracy​(t)=1−1t​K​∑τ=1t∑k=1Kmin⁡{1,|y^k,τ−yk,τ|}.Accuracy𝑡11𝑡𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾1subscript^𝑦𝑘𝜏subscript𝑦𝑘𝜏{\rm Accuracy}(t)=1-\frac{1}{tK}\sum_{\tau=1}^{t}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\min\{1,|\hat{y}_{k,\tau}-y_{k,\tau}|\}.
  • •

    Online regressions:

    MSE​(t)=1t​K​∑τ=1t∑k=1K(y^k,τ−yk,τ)2,MSE𝑡1𝑡𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript^𝑦𝑘𝜏subscript𝑦𝑘𝜏2{\rm MSE}(t)=\frac{1}{tK}\sum_{\tau=1}^{t}\sum_{k=1}^{K}(\hat{y}_{k,\tau}-y_{k,\tau})^{2},

    where in the experiments, labels yk,tsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑡y_{k,t}’s are normalized as yk,t∈[0,1]subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡01y_{k,t}\in[0,1] for ∀k∈[K]for-all𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\forall k\in[K] and ∀t∈[T]for-all𝑡delimited-[]𝑇\forall t\in[T].

To evaluate the communication-cost reduction (CCR) of the communication-efficient (CF) methods (OFedAvg, FedOMD, and OFedIQ) over the baseline method (FedOGD), the following metric is considered:

CCR(%)\displaystyle\mbox{CCR}(\%) =(1−γ)×100,absent1𝛾100\displaystyle=(1-\gamma)\times 100,

where γ=communication-cost of CF-method32​K​D𝛾communication-cost of CF-method32𝐾𝐷\gamma=\frac{\mbox{communication-cost of CF-method}}{32KD} as introduced in Section 4.2. One of the following model architectures will be adopted according to dataset:

  • •

    Model I (CNN): This convolutional neural network (CNN) model consists of two convolutional layers (each with 323232 nodes and 646464 nodes), one softmax layer with 101010 nodes, and 333 bias nodes. Each convolutional layer is composed of multiple sequential operations including convolution, ReLU activation, and max-pooling. A cross-entropy loss function is used. This model contains the 109109109 nodes and accordingly, the number of parameters is equal to D=10×32+289×64+1601×10=34,826formulae-sequence𝐷10322896416011034826D=10\times 32+289\times 64+1601\times 10=34,826.

  • •

    Model II (DNN): This deep neural network (DNN) model consists of two ReLU layer with 646464 nodes, 3 bias nodes, and one softmax layer with 444 nodes. A cross-entropy loss function is considered. This model contains the overall 135135135 nodes and accordingly, the number of parameters is equal to D=2×64+65×64+65×4=4,548formulae-sequence𝐷26465646544548D=2\times 64+65\times 64+65\times 4=4,548.

  • •

    Model III (DNN): This deep neural network (DNN) model consists of two ReLU layer with 646464 nodes, one fc layer with 111 node, and 333 bias nodes. A regularized least-square loss function ℒ​(⋅,⋅)ℒ⋅⋅{\cal L}(\cdot,\cdot) is used. This model contains the 132132132 nodes and accordingly, the number of parameters is equal to D=2×64+65×64+65×1=4,353formulae-sequence𝐷26465646514353D=2\times 64+65\times 64+65\times 1=4,353.

In our experiments, the network has K=1000𝐾1000K=1000 clients each receiving T𝑇T data samples sequentially. The following real datasets are considered:

  • •

    MNIST [32]: The dataset consists of 60,000 samples with 10 handwritten single digits. Each sample has 784 features. The goal is to classify a given handwritten digit into one of 10 classes (integer values from 0 to 9). Model I is used.

  • •

    Room Occupancy Estimation [33]: This dataset contains 10,130 time-series samples with the four classes {0,1,2,3}0123\{0,1,2,3\}. Each sample has 14 features extracted from environmental sensors such as temperature, light, sound, CO2 and PIR. The goal is to predict the precise number of occupants in a room. Model II is used.

  • •

    Air quality [34]: This dataset contains 38,563 time-series samples. Each sample has 5 features including hourly response from an array of 5 metal oxide chemical sensors embedded in a city of Italy. The goal is to estimate the concentration of polluting chemicals in the air. Model III is used.

  • •

    Appliances energy [35]: This dataset contains 18,604 samples, each of which has 252525 features describing appliances energy uses such as temperature and pressure in houses. The goal is to predict energy use in a low-energy building. Model III is used.

For the case of Nb<1000​Tsubscript𝑁𝑏1000𝑇N_{b}<1000T, where Nbsubscript𝑁𝑏N_{b} denotes the number of whole data samples in a dataset, the entire samples are repeated by ⌊1000​T/Nb⌋1000𝑇subscript𝑁𝑏\lfloor 1000T/N_{b}\rfloor times. To study OFL, it is required to specify how data samples in each dataset are distributed across the 100010001000 clients. As in [6], random partitioning is performed, from which the entire 1000​T1000𝑇1000T data samples are shuffled and then partitioned into the K=1000𝐾1000K=1000 clients. The resulting partition is denoted as {𝒟1,…,𝒟K}subscript𝒟1…subscript𝒟𝐾\{{\cal D}_{1},...,{\cal D}_{K}\} with |𝒟k|=T,∀k∈[K]formulae-sequencesubscript𝒟𝑘𝑇for-all𝑘delimited-[]𝐾|{\cal D}_{k}|=T,\forall k\in[K]. At time step t𝑡t, each client k𝑘k receives the data (𝐱k,t,yk,t)subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡({\bf x}_{k,t},y_{k,t}) from 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘{\cal D}_{k} sequentially. Although there are numerous partitions, our experiments confirmed that the performances of the proposed and benchmark methods are not affected by partitions as long as T𝑇T is large. This coincides with our theoretical results as partitions do not change the degree of data-heterogeneity σdiffsubscript𝜎diff\sigma_{\rm diff}.

Performance evaluation: We first validate the analytical results in Section 4 via experiments with MNIST data. Fig. 2 manifests that L=1𝐿1L=1 is the best choice for a fixed p/L𝑝𝐿p/L, which is well-matched with our analysis in Section 4.2.1. Specifically, the performance loss with L>1𝐿1L>1 is noticeable in non-asymptotic case (e.g., t=200𝑡200t=200), whereas it becomes negligible as t𝑡t is sufficiently large. Also, this loss becomes severer as L𝐿L increases. Based on these results and our analysis in Section 4.2.1, to reduce the communication costs as intermittent transmission, client subsampling should be adopted rather than periodic transmission. Fig 3 shows the efficacy of the proposed parameter optimization in Algorithm 3. The optimized OFedIQ(1,0.086,3,777)10.0863777(1,0.086,3,777) outperforms OFedIQ with different parameters such as OFedIQ(1,0.086,7,1)10.08671(1,0.086,7,1) and OFedIQ(1,0.01,∞)10.01(1,0.01,\infty) (a.k.a. OFedAvg(0.01)0.01(0.01)), while having the same communication costs. To the best of our efforts, we could not find other OFedIQ showing better performance than the optimized OFedIQ. Compared with OFedIQ(1,0.086,7,1)10.08671(1,0.086,7,1), the optimized OFedIQ used the proposed stochastic quantization in Definition 2 rather than the stochastic quantization in [30, 11]. From Fig. 3, we can identify the effectiveness of the proposed stochastic quantizer. Moreover, the comparison with FedAvg demonstrates that quantization is indeed useful in order to reduce the communication costs considerably. This supports our theoretical analysis in Section 4.2.2.

Fig. 4 shows the performances of various OFL methods on regression and classification tasks with real datasets. As aforementioned, FedOGD is considered as the performance bound of the communication efficient OFL methods. Regarding the optimized OFedIQ(L,p,s,b)𝐿𝑝𝑠𝑏(L,p,s,b), L=1𝐿1L=1 is chosen from Section 4.2.1, and p𝑝p and (s,b)𝑠𝑏(s,b) are optimized via Algorithm 3. From Fig. 4, we observe that the optimized OFedIQ outperform the benchmark methods for all datasets. Remarkably, it can almost achieve the performance of FedOGD while reducing the communication costs by 99%percent9999\%. Interestingly, FedOMD, which reduces the communication costs via periodic transmission only, yields very poor performances especially when CCR=99%CCRpercent99\mbox{CCR}=99\%. This is because only a small number of global updates are performed. These results strengthen the argument in Section 4.2.1 that periodic transmission is not suitable for OFL. When CCR=90%CCRpercent90\mbox{CCR}=90\%, it seems that quantization is unnecessary since FedAvg has the same performance as the optimized OFedIQ. To further reduce the communication costs (e.g., CCR=99%CCRpercent99\mbox{CCR}=99\%), however, the optimized quantization is indeed effective. Thus, the optimized OFedIQ can provide a more elegant tradeoff of performance and communication costs than FedAvg. Our experimental results suggest the practicality of the optimized OFedIQ.

6 Conclusion

We presented a communication-efficient method (named OFedIQ) for online federated learning (OFL) by means of client subsampling, periodic transmission, and quantization. Through our tighter regret analysis, it was proved that OFedIQ can enjoy an optimal sublinear regret for any real dataset (up to a constant) while significantly reducing the communication costs of FedOGD (i.e., the performance-limit). On the basis of our analysis, moreover, we efficiently optimized the key parameters of OFedIQ such as the sampling rate, the transmission period, and quantization levels. Via experiments with real datasets, we demonstrated the effectiveness of our algorithm on various online classification and regression tasks. Specifically, for all datasets in our experiments, the optimized OFedIQ outperforms the state-of-the-art OFL methods. In addition, it can almost achieve the performances of FedOGD while reducing the communication costs by 99%percent9999\%. These results suggest the practicality of the optimized OFedIQ.
